title: Remand status at Crown Court
measure_summary:
This data measures the percentage of defendants in the Crown Court, within different ethnic groups, who are remanded on bail or custody, or not remanded.

Remand is the way that people who are charged with a crime (‘defendants’) are dealt with until the court hearings for that crime are completed. They can be:

* remanded on bail, meaning they are allowed to return home until the court hearing (sometimes with certain conditions)
* remanded in custody, which means they will be held in prison
* not remanded, meaning they have not been given bail or custody at some point during the proceedings

After arrest, the police will decide a defendant’s remand status (bail or custody), which lasts until their first court hearing at the magistrates’ court. After that, the courts will decide the defendant’s remand status at each hearing in the proceedings. Different remand decisions for the same defendant may be made during the court process. 

Some offences are dealt with entirely in the magistrates’ court, but others (usually more serious offences) go from there to the Crown Court. This data focuses on defendants in the Crown Court.

Defendants are also classified by age group, so that:

* adults are aged 21 and over
* young adults are aged 18 to 20
* juveniles are under the age of 18

The data is taken from the Ministry of Justice's case management system for the Crown Court (CREST).
summary:
* in 2016, the percentage of defendants at the Crown Court remanded in custody fell for all ethnic groups compared to the years from 2012 to 2015

* in 2016, Black defendants were more likely than any other ethnic group to be remanded in custody

* from 2012 to 2016, White defendants were consistently less likely to be remanded in custody, and consistently more likely to have a remand status of ‘not remanded’, than any other ethnic group
need_to_know:
The Ministry of Justice's case management system (CREST) only gives data for remand in the Crown Court. Magistrates' courts are not included because there is not enough ethnicity data for offences dealt with by those courts. This also means that defendants who originally appeared in a magistrates' court, and later appeared in the Crown Court, will not be counted twice.

If a defendant has more than one remand status during court proceedings, only the most serious status will be recorded. For example, if a defendant is remanded on bail and then later remanded in custody, their status will be recorded as custody. 

The data does not include details of the offence for which the defendant has been charged. It is likely that the severity of the offence will influence the type of remand status (bail or custody) given to the defendant.
ethnicity_definition_summary:
The analysis uses the following broad ethnic categories, based on the 2001 Census:

* White
* Mixed / Multiple ethnic groups
* Asian / Asian British
* Black / African / Caribbean / Black British
* Other ethnic group (which includes Chinese)

There is also a ‘not stated’ category, which is made up of people whose ethnicity has not been recorded or who chose not to state their ethnicity.
data_source_purpose: The Ministry of Justice's case management system (CREST) provides key statistics on activity in the Criminal Justice System (CJS) for England and Wales. The data provides users with information about proven offending and its outcomes in England and Wales. The content will be of interest to government policy makers in the development of policy and their subsequent monitoring and evaluation. Others will be interested in the way different crimes are dealt with in the CJS.
methodology:
The analysis uses administrative data from the Crown Court (CREST). The data counts individual people (defendants) not cases. Multiple defendants are counted for one case where applicable. Each defendant is only counted once, even if multiple offences are committed. When a defendant has been found guilty of two or more offences it is the offence for which the heaviest penalty is imposed. 

Every effort is made to ensure that the figures presented are accurate and complete. However, it is important to note that this data has been extracted from large administrative data systems generated by the courts and police forces. As a consequence, care should be taken to ensure data collection processes and their inevitable limitations are taken into account when this data is used.
estimation: Data is rounded to 1 decimal place

dimensions.title: Remand status at Crown Court by ethnicity
dimensions.summary:
This data shows that:

* in 2016, defendants in each ethnic group were more likely to be remanded on bail than to be remanded in custody

* from 2012 to 2015, Black defendants were more likely to be remanded in custody than any other outcome, but in 2016, they were more likely to be remanded on bail

* from 2012 to 2016, defendants from White and Asian ethnic groups were least likely to be remanded in custody compared to other groups

dimensions.title: Remand status at Crown Court by ethnicity and gender
dimensions.summary:
This data shows that:

* from 2012 to 2016, in each ethnic group male defendants were more likely than female defendants to be remanded in custody

dimensions.title: Remand status at Crown Court by ethnicity and age group
dimensions.summary:
This data shows that:

* between 2014 and 2016, the percentage of Asian juvenile defendants remanded in custody doubled, from 21% in 2014 to 43% in 2016

* in 2016, Black juvenile and young adult defendants ethnic backgrounds were more likely to be remanded in custody then remanded on bail, unlike most other groups
